description: This virtual science lab uses the My Solar System Lab Simulation app to explore the dynamics of the solar system. Students will engage in a case-study method to investigate the relationships between mass, distance, and gravitational forces in planetary motion.

learningGoals.bigIdea: The gravitational interactions between celestial bodies govern the structure and behavior of the solar system.
objectives: Understand how mass and distance affect gravitational forces.
Analyze the relationship between orbital speed and distance from the sun.
Investigate how changes in mass impact orbital dynamics.
Explore the interactions of multiple bodies within the solar system.
successCriteria: Demonstrate the ability to manipulate simulation parameters effectively.
Accurately document observations and data collected during the simulation.
Make informed predictions based on scientific reasoning.
Engage in critical thinking about the relationships and dynamics within the solar system.

labParts.title: Investigating Gravitational Forces
setup: Open the My Solar System Lab Simulation app.
Set the mass of the sun to 250.0 (10^28 kg) and the mass of a planet to 25.0 (10^28 kg).
Adjust the distance between the sun and the planet to 1 AU.
Start the simulation and observe the motion.
observations: How does the planet's orbit change as you adjust its mass?
What happens to the gravitational force as the distance between the sun and the planet is altered?
How does the planet's speed change in relation to its distance from the sun?
evidence: Document the gravitational force and orbital speed in a CSV file.
predictions: What will happen to the planet's orbit if its mass is increased?
How will the gravitational force change if the distance is doubled?

labParts.title: Effect of Distance on Orbital Speed
setup: Reset the simulation.
Keep the mass of the sun at 250.0 (10^28 kg) and the mass of the planet at 25.0 (10^28 kg).
Set the distance to 2 AU and start the simulation.
Record the planet's orbital speed.
observations: What differences do you notice in the planet's speed at 2 AU compared to 1 AU?
How does the gravitational pull affect the planet's speed at this distance?
Does the planet maintain a consistent speed throughout its orbit?
evidence: Record the planet's orbital speed at both distances in a CSV file.
predictions: How will the orbital speed change if the distance is increased to 3 AU?
What do you think will happen if the distance is decreased to 0.5 AU?

labParts.title: Mass and Orbital Dynamics
setup: Reset the simulation.
Set the mass of the sun to 250.0 (10^28 kg).
Set the mass of the planet to 50.0 (10^28 kg).
Maintain the distance at 1 AU and start the simulation.
observations: How does the increased mass of the planet affect its orbit?
What changes do you observe in the gravitational force exerted on the planet?
How does this mass change impact the planet's speed?
evidence: Document the gravitational force and orbital speed in a CSV file.
predictions: How might the planet's orbit change if its mass were decreased to 10.0 (10^28 kg)?
What would happen if both the sun and planet masses were increased simultaneously?

labParts.title: Exploring Multiple Bodies in the System
setup: Reset the simulation.
Set the mass of the sun to 250.0 (10^28 kg).
Set the mass of two planets: one at 25.0 (10^28 kg) and another at 10.0 (10^28 kg).
Set the distances to 1 AU and 1.5 AU respectively, then start the simulation.
observations: How do the orbits of the two planets interact with each other?
What happens to the gravitational forces acting on each planet?
How do the speeds of the planets compare to each other?
evidence: Collect data on the orbits and speeds of both planets in a CSV file.
predictions: What will happen if the distance between the two planets is reduced?
How might the orbits change if one planet's mass is significantly increased?

description: This virtual science lab explores the principles of natural selection using a simulation app, allowing students to manipulate variables and observe outcomes in a controlled environment.

learningGoals.bigIdea: Natural selection drives the evolution of species by favoring beneficial traits.
objectives: Understand the concept of natural selection.
Examine the impact of environmental changes on species survival.
Analyze the role of genetic mutations in evolution.
Evaluate data to draw conclusions about evolutionary processes.
successCriteria: Accurately manipulate simulation variables and document outcomes.
Make predictions based on observations and justify them.
Collect and analyze data effectively to support claims.
Demonstrate understanding of natural selection through thoughtful reflections.

labParts.title: Introduction to Natural Selection
setup: Launch the Natural Selection Lab Simulation app.
Select the 'Rabbits vs. Wolves' scenario.
Set initial parameters: Habitat to 'Savanna', Wolves to 'Few', and Food Supply to 'Normal'.
observations: What variations in rabbit color can you see in the initial population?
How do rabbits react to the presence of wolves?
What environmental factors might impact the rabbit population?
evidence: Collect data on rabbit population and traits in a CSV file after each generation.
predictions: How do you think the rabbit population will change over the next few generations?
What traits will be favored as natural selection occurs?

labParts.title: Simulating Environmental Changes
setup: Continue in the simulation and change the Habitat to 'Forest'.
Increase the number of Wolves to 'Some'.
Set Food Supply to 'Scarce'.
observations: How does the change in habitat affect rabbit survival?
What changes do you notice in the wolf population?
How do the rabbits' traits change in response to these new conditions?
evidence: Document the changes in rabbit and wolf populations in a CSV file after each generation.
predictions: What will happen to the rabbit population with increased predation?
Which rabbit traits will likely become more common in this environment?

labParts.title: Exploring Mutations and Variation
setup: In the simulation, set the Mutation Rate to 'High variation'.
Keep the previous parameters: Habitat as 'Forest', Wolves as 'Some', Food Supply as 'Scarce'.
observations: What new traits appear in the rabbit population due to mutations?
How do these mutations impact rabbit survival against wolves?
Are there any traits that seem to be disadvantageous?
evidence: Record the variations in traits and their survival rates in a CSV file after running the simulation.
predictions: How might increased mutations affect the overall rabbit population?
Which traits are likely to persist or vanish in future generations?

labParts.title: Analyzing Data and Formulating Conclusions
setup: Review the data collected from previous parts.
Compare the rabbit populations and traits across different generations.
observations: What trends do you notice in the rabbit population over generations?
How did the presence of predators influence trait selection?
What can you conclude about the relationship between environment and evolution?
evidence: Summarize your findings in a CSV file, including population changes and trait success.
predictions: What implications do your findings have for understanding real-world ecosystems?
How could this simulation inform conservation efforts?
